My Bookshelf

Books I felt the most alive while reading

Generally, I‚Äôm up for reading anything. Be it history, engineering or metaphysics. Nevertheless, there are some books I‚Äôve really loved reading. I would definitely suggest you to have a look at them too (not necessarily in an order).

P.S. Metaphysics is starkly different from Physics, btw üòù

Self-help

  1. How to Stop Worrying and Start Living by Dale Carnegie ‚Äî This is seriously one of those books which everyone of this hustling era has to read. It‚Äôs like an instruction manual for being totally worry-free.
  2. The Greatest Salesman in the World by Og Mandino ‚Äî A short but very impactful book which unravels an intriguing story whilst putting forth the 10 most important traits to make the world yours.
  3. The Subtle Art of not Giving a F*ck by Mark Manson ‚Äî Now, this one‚Äôs very different from the other books in this genre. By different I mean the unique and badass writing style of Mark Manson. Sometimes shocking, sometimes stern but always insightful.

Non-fiction

  1. Sapiens by Yuval Noah Harari ‚Äî If you love general science and would love to get some food for thought about how Homo Sapiens came to this very stage, Sapiens would do just that. It is like a well-mixed concoction of Harari‚Äôs opinions/hypotheses and proofs of some actual phenomena.
  2. Ikigai by H√©ctor Garc√≠a and Francesc Miralles ‚Äî I‚Äôve seen a lot of reviews complaining about this one. Although, I thoroughly appreciate it. The book sheds light on a myriad things which are pretty essential for living a healthy lifestyle (happy follows, doesn‚Äôt it?).

Fiction

  1. The Da Vinci Code and Angels and Demons by Dan Brown ‚Äî I have literally been hooked on to these books from the start to end. These 2 books are so full of thrill and intricate writing that they just teleport you to a new dimension.
  2. All-night Party by R.L. Stine (quite an old one) ‚Äî A perfect bite-sized thriller for that lonely flight trip that just popped up in your life out of nowhere. Maybe a bit childish but it was pretty fun.
